description: From Middle English [Term?], from Old French tribut, from Latin tributum (“tribute”, literally “a thing contributed or paid”), neuter of tributus, past participle of tribuō (“to assign, allot”), usually derived from tribus (“tribe”). See tribe.

definitionGroups.group: An acknowledgment of gratitude, respect or admiration; an accompanying gift.

entries.meaning: An homage made in a body of work to another work or creator.
examples: Did you catch the Up in Smoke tribute in that episode of That '70s Show?

entries.meaning: A payment made by one nation to another in submission.
examples: The Ancient Romans made their conquered countries pay tribute.

entries.meaning: A payment made by a feudal vassal to his lord.
(mining) A certain proportion of the mined ore, or of its value, given to the miner as payment.
examples: The setting of a Copper Mine upon tribute , has this difference : the Tributor is at the sole expence of digging , raising , and dressing , all the Ore that can be made merchantable

verbs.description: tribute (third-person singular simple present tributes, present participle tributing, simple past and past participle tributed)
